etymologies: early 20th century. From scientific Latin Agastache, genus name (J. F. GronoviusFlora Virginica 88) from ancient Greek ἄγαν very much (probably originally showing the accusative of ἄγη wonder) + στάχυς ear of corn, so called on account of the multiple flowering spikes of the plant

definitions: Any of various perennial plants constituting the genus Agastache (family Lamiaceae (Labiatae)), native chiefly to North America, having multiple spikes of tubular pink to purple flowers and scented leaves; especially (in later use) any of the many cultivated varieties grown in gardens for ornament. Also (in form Agastache): the genus itself.
